migrate.description: Migrate legacy messaging subsystem resources to the new messaging-activemq subsystem

*.description: A JMS bridge instance.

add-messageID-in-header.description: If true, then the original message's message ID will be appended in the message sent to the destination in the header HORNETQ_BRIDGE_MSG_ID_LIST. If the message is bridged more than once, each message ID will be appended.

client-id.description: The JMS client ID to use when creating/looking up the subscription if it is durable and the source destination is a topic.

failure-retry-interval.description: The amount of time in milliseconds to wait between trying to recreate connections to the source or target servers when the bridge has detected they have failed.

max-batch-size.description: The maximum number of messages to consume from the source destination before sending them in a batch to the target destination. Its value must >= 1.

max-batch-time.description: The maximum number of milliseconds to wait before sending a batch to target, even if the number of messages consumed has not reached max-batch-size. Its value must be -1 to represent 'wait forever', or >= 1 to specify an actual time.

max-retries.description: The number of times to attempt to recreate connections to the source or target servers when the bridge has detected they have failed. The bridge will give up after trying this number of times. -1 represents 'try forever'.

module.description: The name of AS7 module containing the resources required to lookup source and target JMS resources.

paused.description: Whether the JMS bridge is paused.

quality-of-service.description: The desired quality of service mode (AT_MOST_ONCE, DUPLICATES_OK or ONCE_AND_ONLY_ONCE).

selector.description: A JMS selector expression used for consuming messages from the source destination. Only messages that match the selector expression will be bridged from the source to the target destination.

source-connection-factory.description: The name of the source connection factory to lookup on the source messaging server.

source-context-property.description: The properties used to configure the source JNDI initial context.

source-destination.description: The name of the source destination to lookup on the source messaging server.

source-password.description: The password for creating the source connection.

source-user.description: The name of the user for creating the source connection.

started.description: Whether the JMS bridge is started.

subscription-name.description: The name of the subscription if it is durable and the source destination is a topic.

target-connection-factory.description: The name of the target connection factory to lookup on the target messaging server.

target-context-property.description: The properties used to configure the target JNDI initial context.

target-destination.description: The name of the target destination to lookup on the target messaging server.

target-password.description: The password for creating the target connection.

target-user.description: The name of the user for creating the target connection.

source-destination.description: The name of the source destination to lookup on the source messaging server.

source-password.description: The password for creating the source connection.

source-user.description: The name of the user for creating the source connection.

subscription-name.description: The name of the subscription if it is durable and the source destination is a topic.

target-connection-factory.description: The name of the target connection factory to lookup on the target messaging server.

*.description: An ActiveMQ server instance.

active.description: Whether the server is active (and accepting connections) or passive (in backup mode, waiting for failover).

async-connection-execution-enabled.description: Whether incoming packets on the server should be handed off to a thread from the thread pool for processing. False if they should be handled on the remoting thread.

connection-ttl-override.description: If set, this will override how long (in ms) to keep a connection alive without receiving a ping.

id-cache-size.description: The size of the cache for pre-creating message IDs.

page-max-concurrent-io.description: The maximum number of concurrent reads allowed on paging

persist-delivery-count-before-delivery.description: Whether the delivery count is persisted before delivery. False means that this only happens after a message has been cancelled.

persist-id-cache.description: Whether IDs are persisted to the journal.

persistence-enabled.description: Whether the server will use the file based journal for persistence.

scheduled-thread-pool-max-size.description: The number of threads that the main scheduled thread pool has.

thread-pool-max-size.description: The number of threads that the main thread pool has. -1 means no limit.

wild-card-routing-enabled.description: Whether the server supports wild card routing.

cluster-password.description: The password used by cluster connections to communicate between the clustered nodes.

cluster-user.description: The user used by cluster connections to communicate between the clustered nodes.

memory-measure-interval.description: Frequency to sample JVM memory in ms (or -1 to disable memory sampling)

memory-warning-threshold.description: Percentage of available memory which if exceeded results in a warning log

run-sync-speed-test.description: Whether on startup to perform a diagnostic test on how fast your disk can sync. Useful when determining performance issues.

server-dump-interval.description: How often to dump basic runtime information to the server log. A value less than 1 disables this feature.

create-bindings-dir.description: Whether the server should create the bindings directory on start up.

create-journal-dir.description: Whether the server should create the journal directory on start up.

journal-buffer-size.description: The size of the internal buffer on the journal.

journal-buffer-timeout.description: The timeout (in nanoseconds) used to flush internal buffers on the journal.

journal-compact-min-files.description: The minimal number of journal data files before we can start compacting.

journal-compact-percentage.description: The percentage of live data on which we consider compacting the journal.

journal-file-size.description: The size (in bytes) of each journal file.

journal-max-io.description: The maximum number of write requests that can be in the AIO queue at any one time.

journal-min-files.description: How many journal files to pre-create.

journal-sync-non-transactional.description: Whether to wait for non transaction data to be synced to the journal before returning a response to the client.

journal-sync-transactional.description: Whether to wait for transaction data to be synchronized to the journal before returning a response to the client.

journal-type.description: The type of journal to use.

log-journal-write-rate.description: Whether to periodically log the journal's write rate and flush rate.

jmx-domain.description: The JMX domain used to register internal HornetQ MBeans in the MBeanServer.

jmx-management-enabled.description: Whether HornetQ should expose its internal management API via JMX. This is not recommended, as accessing these MBeans can lead to inconsistent configuration.

management-address.description: Address to send management messages to.

management-notification-address.description: The name of the address that consumers bind to  to receive management notifications.

message-expiry-scan-period.description: How often (in ms) to scan for expired messages.

message-expiry-thread-priority.description: The priority of the thread expiring messages.

remoting-incoming-interceptors.description: The list of incoming interceptor classes used by this server.

remoting-outgoing-interceptors.description: The list of outgoing interceptor classes used by this server.

override-in-vm-security.description: Whether the HornetQ server will override security credentials for in-vm connections.

security-domain.description: The security domain to use to verify user and role information

security-invalidation-interval.description: How long (in ms) to wait before invalidating the security cache.

message-counter-max-day-history.description: How many days to keep message counter history.

message-counter-sample-period.description: The sample period (in ms) to use for message counters.

statistics-enabled.description: Whether gathering of statistics such as message counters are enabled.

transaction-timeout.description: How long (in ms) before a transaction can be removed from the resource manager after create time.

transaction-timeout-scan-period.description: How often (in ms) to scan for timeout transactions.

reply-properties.description: The creation time, represented as a string showing the number of milliseconds since the epoch.

divert.description: A messaging resource that allows you to transparently divert messages routed to one address to some other address, without making any changes to any client application logic.

*.description: A messaging resource that allows you to transparently divert messages routed to one address to some other address, without making any changes to any client application logic.

exclusive.description: Whether the divert is exclusive, meaning that the message is diverted to the new address, and does not go to the old address at all.

filter.description: An optional filter string. If specified then only messages which match the filter expression specified will be diverted. The filter string follows the HornetQ filter expression syntax described in the HornetQ documentation.

transformer-class-name.description: The name of a class used to transform the message's body or properties before it is diverted.

core-address.description: A runtime-only resource representing a HornetQ "address". Zero or more queues can be bound to a single address. When a message is routed, it is routed to the set of queues bound to the message's address.

cluster-connection.description: Cluster connections group servers into clusters so that messages can be load balanced between the nodes of the cluster.

*.description: Cluster connections group servers into clusters so that messages can be load balanced between the nodes of the cluster.

allow-direct-connections-only.description: Whether, if a node learns of the existence of a node that is more than 1 hop away, we do not create a bridge for direct cluster connection. Only relevant if 'static-connectors' is defined.

call-failover-timeout.description: The timeout to use when fail over is in process (in ms) for remote calls made by the cluster connection.

call-timeout.description: The timeout (in ms) for remote calls made by the cluster connection.

check-period.description: The period (in milliseconds) between client failure check.

cluster-connection-address.description: Each cluster connection only applies to messages sent to an address that starts with this value.

confirmation-window-size.description: The confirmation-window-size to use for the connection used to forward messages to a target node.

connection-ttl.description: The maximum time (in milliseconds) for which the connections used by the cluster connections are considered alive (in the absence of heartbeat).

connector-name.description: The name of connector to use for live connection

discovery-group.description: The discovery group used to obtain the list of other servers in the cluster to which this cluster connection will make connections. Must be {} (null) if 'static-connectors' is defined.

forward-when-no-consumers.description: Whether messages will be distributed round robin between other nodes of the cluster irrespective of whether there are matching or indeed any consumers on other nodes. If this is set to false (the default) then HornetQ will only forward messages to other nodes of the cluster if the address to which they are being forwarded has queues which have consumers, and if those consumers have message filters (selectors) at least one of those selectors must match the message.

initial-connect-attempts.description: The number of attempts to connect initially with this cluster connection.

max-hops.description: The maximum number of times a message can be forwarded. HornetQ can be configured to also load balance messages to nodes which might be connected to it only indirectly with other HornetQ servers as intermediates in a chain.

max-retry-interval.description: The maximum interval of time used to retry connections

min-large-message-size.description: The minimum size (in bytes) for a message before it is considered as a large message.

node-id.description: The node ID used by this cluster connection.

notification-attempts.description: How many times the cluster connection will broadcast itself

notification-interval.description: How often the cluster connection will broadcast itself

reconnect-attempts.description: The total number of reconnect attempts the bridge will make before giving up and shutting down. A value of -1 signifies an unlimited number of attempts.

retry-interval.description: The period in milliseconds between subsequent attempts to reconnect to a target server, if the connection to the target server has failed.

retry-interval-multiplier.description: A multiplier to apply to the time since the last retry to compute the time to the next retry. This allows you to implement an exponential backoff between retry attempts.

started.description: Whether the cluster connection is started.

static-connectors.description: The statically defined list of connectors to which this cluster connection will make connections. Must be {} (null) if 'discovery-group-name' is defined.

topology.description: The topology of the nodes that this cluster connection is aware of.

use-duplicate-detection.description: Whether the bridge will automatically insert a duplicate id property into each message that it forwards.

get-nodes.description: Returns a map of the nodes connected to this cluster connection, where keys are node IDs and values are the addresses used to connect to the nodes.

reply-properties.description: A map where keys are node IDs and values are the addresses used to connect to the nodes.

path.description: A filesystem path pointing to one of the locations where HornetQ stores persistent data.

journal-directory.description: A filesystem path pointing to one of the locations where HornetQ stores persistent data.

path.description:
The actual filesystem path. Treated as an absolute path, unless the 'relative-to' attribute is specified, in which case the value is treated as relative to that path.

If treated as an absolute path, the actual runtime pathname specified by the value of this attribute will be determined as follows:

If this value is already absolute, then the value is directly used. Otherwise the runtime pathname is resolved in a system-dependent way. On UNIX systems, a relative pathname is made absolute by resolving it against the current user directory. On Microsoft Windows systems, a relative pathname is made absolute by resolving it against the current directory of the drive named by the pathname, if any; if not, it is resolved against the current user directory.

relative-to.description:
The name of another previously named path, or of one of the standard paths provided by the system. If 'relative-to' is provided, the value of the 'path' attribute is treated as relative to the path specified by this attribute. The standard paths provided by the system include:
  • jboss.home - the root directory of the JBoss AS distribution
  • user.home - user's home directory
  • user.dir - user's current working directory
  • java.home - java installation directory
  • jboss.server.base.dir - root directory for an individual server instance
  • jboss.server.data.dir - directory the server will use for persistent data file storage
  • jboss.server.log.dir - directory the server will use for log file storage
  • jboss.server.tmp.dir - directory the server will use for temporary file storage
  • jboss.domain.servers.dir - directory under which a host controller will create the working area for individual server instances

resolve-path.description: Resolves a relative path of a previously named paths or one of the standard paths provided by the system.

relative-to-only.description: Indicates whether only the relative-to attribute should be resolved or the full path should be resolved. The default is false meaning the entire path will be resolved.

reply-properties.description: The resolved path from the relative path attribute.

  • user.home - user's home directory
  • user.dir - user's current working directory
  • java.home - java installation directory
  • jboss.server.base.dir - root directory for an individual server instance
  • jboss.server.data.dir - directory the server will use for persistent data file storage
  • jboss.server.log.dir - directory the server will use for log file storage
  • jboss.server.tmp.dir - directory the server will use for temporary file storage
  • jboss.domain.servers.dir - directory under which a host controller will create the working area for individual server instances

path.description:
The actual filesystem path. Treated as an absolute path, unless the 'relative-to' attribute is specified, in which case the value is treated as relative to that path.

If treated as an absolute path, the actual runtime pathname specified by the value of this attribute will be determined as follows:

If this value is already absolute, then the value is directly used. Otherwise the runtime pathname is resolved in a system-dependent way. On UNIX systems, a relative pathname is made absolute by resolving it against the current user directory. On Microsoft Windows systems, a relative pathname is made absolute by resolving it against the current directory of the drive named by the pathname, if any; if not, it is resolved against the current user directory.

bridge.description: The function of a bridge is to consume messages from a source queue, and forward them to a target address, typically on a different HornetQ server.

*.description: The function of a bridge is to consume messages from a source queue, and forward them to a target address, typically on a different HornetQ server.

check-period.description: The period (in milliseconds) between client failure check.

confirmation-window-size.description: The confirmation-window-size to use for the connection used to forward messages to the target node.

connection-ttl.description: The maximum time (in milliseconds) for which the connections used by the bridges are considered alive (in the absence of heartbeat).

discovery-group.description: The name of the discovery group used by this bridge. Must be {} (null) if 'static-connectors' is defined.

filter.description: An optional filter string. If specified then only messages which match the filter expression specified will be forwarded. The filter string follows the HornetQ filter expression syntax described in the HornetQ documentation.

forwarding-address.description: The address on the target server that the message will be forwarded to. If a forwarding address is not specified then the original destination of the message will be retained.

ha.description: Whether or not this bridge should support high availability. True means it will connect to any available server in a cluster and support failover.

initial-connect-attempts.description: The number of attempts to connect initially with this bridge.

max-retry-interval.description: The maximum interval of time used to retry connections

min-large-message-size.description: The minimum size (in bytes) for a message before it is considered as a large message.

password.description: The password to use when creating the bridge connection to the remote server. If it is not specified the default cluster password specified by the cluster-password attribute in the root messaging subsystem resource will be used.

queue-name.description: The unique name of the local queue that the bridge consumes from.

reconnect-attempts.description: The total number of reconnect attempts the bridge will make before giving up and shutting down. A value of -1 signifies an unlimited number of attempts.

reconnect-attempts-on-same-node.description: The total number of reconnect attempts on the same node the bridge will make before giving up and shutting down. A value of -1 signifies an unlimited number of attempts.

retry-interval.description: The period in milliseconds between subsequent reconnection attempts, if the connection to the target server has failed.

retry-interval-multiplier.description: A multiplier to apply to the time since the last retry to compute the time to the next retry. This allows you to implement an exponential backoff between retry attempts.

static-connectors.description: A list of names of statically defined connectors used by this bridge. Must be {} (null) if 'discovery-group-name' is defined.

transformer-class-name.description: The name of a user-defined class which implements the org.hornetq.core.server.cluster.Transformer interface.

use-duplicate-detection.description: Whether the bridge will automatically insert a duplicate id property into each message that it forwards.

user.description: The user name to use when creating the bridge connection to the remote server. If it is not specified the default cluster user specified by the cluster-user attribute in the root messaging subsystem resource will be used.

discovery-group.description: Multicast group to listen to receive broadcast from other servers announcing their connectors.

*.description: Multicast group to listen to receive broadcast from other servers announcing their connectors.

initial-wait-timeout.description: Period, in ms, to wait for an initial broadcast to give us at least one node in the cluster.

jgroups-channel.description: The name used by a JGroups channel to join a cluster.

jgroups-stack.description: The name of a stack defined in the org.jboss.as.clustering.jgroups subsystem that is used to form a cluster.

refresh-timeout.description: Period the discovery group waits after receiving the last broadcast from a particular server before removing that server's connector pair entry from its list.
